column4: Time OntologyI. Time: The indefinite continued progress of existence and events that occur in apparently irreversible succession from the past, through the present, into the future.  A. Units of Time     1. Second: The fundamental unit of time.        a. Nanosecond        b. Microsecond        c. Millisecond     2. Minute: Contains 60 seconds     3. Hour: Contains 60 minutes     4. Day: Contains 24 hours.     5. Week: Contains 7 days.     6. Month: A period of time that roughly corresponds with the moon's synodic period        a. Lunar Month        b. Gregorian Month     7. Year: A period of time that approximates the time needed for the earth to complete one orbit around the sun.        a. Calendar Year        b. Fiscal Year        c. Astronomical Year        d. Leap Year     8. Decade: Contains 10 years.     9. Century: Contains 100 years.     10. Millennium: Contains 1000 years.      B. Measurement of Time      1. Clock: An instrument to measure, keep, and indicate time         a. Wall Clock         b. Alarm Clock         c. Stopwatch         d. Hourglass      2. Calendar: A system of organizing days for social, religious, commercial, or administrative purposes.      3. Sundial: Uses the position of the sun to indicate the time.         C. Concepts of Time      1. Past: The time before now.      2. Present: The time occurring now.      3. Future: The time yet to come.      4. Eternity: Infinite or unending time.      5. Temporality: The state of existing within or having some relationship with time.      6. Time Travel: The concept of movement between certain points in time.  D. Process of Time      1. Aging: The process of becoming older.      2. Growth: The process of increasing in size.      3. Decay: The process of decline in quality, power, or vigor.      4. Evolution: The process by which different kinds of living organisms developed and diversified from earlier forms during the history of earth.         E. Time Zones      - Definition: A region of the globe that observes a uniform standard time for legal, commercial, and social purposes.      1. Pacific Time      2. Mountain Time      3. Central Time      4. Eastern Time      5. Greenwich Mean Time      6. Coordinated Universal Time  F. Cultural and Scientific Theories of Time      1. Linear Time      2. Cyclical Time      3. Einstein's Theory of Relativity      4. Quantum Mechanics      5. The Arrow of Time.      6. The Big Bang Theory.

column4: Concept: Time1. Sub-Concepts:   - 1.1 Past: The period of time that has gone before.         - 1.1.1 Event: Something that took place or happened in the past.        - 1.1.2 History: The study of past events.        - 1.1.3 Yesterday: The day before today.   - 1.2 Present: The current moment or period of time.        - 1.2.1 Now: The current moment.        - 1.2.2 Today: The present day.   - 1.3 Future: The period of time that is yet to come.        - 1.3.1 Tomorrow: The day after today.        - 1.3.2 Forecast: Predictions concerning future events.        - 1.3.3 Potential Events: Events that may happen in the future.   2. Properties of Time:   - 2.1 Finite: Time has a beginning and an end.   - 2.2 Continuity: Time is continuous and unbroken.3. Relationships in Time:   - 3.1 Chronological Order: Events arranged in time.   - 3.2 Time Interval: The amount of time between two events.   - 3.3 Time Duration: The length of time an event lasts.   - 3.4 Co-Occurrence: Two or more events happening at the same time.4. Instruments of Time:   - 4.1 Clock: Measures time in hours and minutes.   - 4.2 Calendar: Measures longer periods of time in days, weeks, months, & years.   - 4.3 Stopwatch: Measures precise spans of time.   - 4.4 Sundial: Measures time based on the position of the sun.5. Units of Time:   - 5.1 Seconds: The base unit of time.   - 5.2 Minutes: Comprised of 60 seconds.   - 5.3 Hours: Comprised of 60 minutes.   - 5.4 Days: Comprised of 24 hours.   - 5.5 Weeks: Comprised of 7 days.   - 5.6 Months: Roughly comprised of 30 days.   - 5.7 Years: Comprised of about 12 months or 365 days.   - 5.8 Decades: Comprised of 10 years.   - 5.9 Centuries: Comprised of 100 years.   - 5.10 Millenniums: Comprised of 1,000 years. 6. Time in Culture:    - 6.1 Mythology: Different cultures have various gods and deities representing time.    - 6.2 Philoophy: Various philosophies on the nature of time.    - 6.3 Literature: Time often plays a crucial role in narratives and story-telling.    - 6.4 Science: The study of time in relation to physics, cosmology, etc.   7. Time Theory:    - 7.1 Linear: Time proceeds in a straight line from past to future.    - 7.2 Cyclical: Time is seen as repeating in cycles.    - 7.3 Time Travel: The hypothetical concept of moving between different points in time.    - 7.4 Multiverse: Multiple universes existing concurrently in different timelines.

column4: Ontology Concepts:1. Time: The key concept of this ontology. It is measured or measurable period, a continuum that lacks spatial dimensions.2. Past: Period of time that has already happened, in contrast to the present and the future. 3. Present: The period of time occurring now. 4. Future: The period of time that will come after the present or the time that is yet to come.5. Second: The base unit of time in the international system of units. 6. Minute: A unit of time equal to sixty seconds or a sixtieth of an hour.7. Hour: A unit of time equal to sixty minutes. 8. Day: A unit of time. In common usage, it is an interval equal to 24 hours. It also can be used to refer to a period of light (daylight hours) as opposed to night.9. Week: A period of seven days.10. Month: A unit of time, used with calendars, which is approximately as long as a natural period related to the motion of the Moon.11. Year: A unit of time usually representing 12 months or 365 or 366 days.12. Decade: A period of 10 years.13. Century: A period of 100 years.14. Millennium: A period of 1000 years.15. Time Zone: A region of the Earth that has the same standard time.16. Daylight Saving Time: The practice of setting the clock ahead by one hour from standard time during the warmer part of the year, so evenings have more daylight and mornings have less.17. Leap Year: A year, occurring once every four years, which has 366 days including February 29 as an extra day.18. Timeline: A visual representation of a chronological sequence of events.19. Workday: The period of the day during which one is at work.20. Break Time: A short period of time when you stop working and relax.Relationships:- Second is part of Minute- Minute is part of Hour- Hour is part of Day- Day is part of Week- Week is part of Month- Month is part of Year- Year is part of Decade- Decade is part of Century- Century is part of Millennium- Past, Present, Future are part of Time- Time Zone, Daylight Saving Time are related to Day- Leap Year is related to Year- Workday, Break Time are part of Day- Timeline is related to Past, Present, Future.

Below is an ontology based on the concept of "Time".1. **Temporal Units:** These are the basic units used to measure time, such as seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, months, years, decades, centuries, and millennia.2. **Clock Time:** This pertains to the system of measuring time according to hours and minutes on a clock.3. **Calendar Time:** This pertains to the system of organizing and measuring time into days, weeks, months, and years, typically seen in a calendar.4. **Historical Time:** This refers to the chronological order of past events or periods.5. **Geological Time:** This deals with the timescale over which geological processes occur, from seconds to millions of years.6. **Biological Time:** This concerns the timescale over which biological processes occur, typically tied to circadian rhythms, seasons, life cycles, and evolutionary time.7. **Physical Time:** This is a concept in physics relating to the progression of events from the past to the present into the future.8. **Astronomical Time:** The concept of time that pertains to sky observation, distances between celestial bodies, cosmic events, etc.9. **Relative Time:** This refers to a measure of time based on non-standard, varying measurements, like 'dinner time' or 'bed time'.10. **Human Perception of Time:** The subjective experience and awareness of time, which includes psychological concepts such as past, present, future, the feeling of time passing quickly or slowly, timelessness, etc.11. **Time Zones:** These are regions of the Earth that have the same standard time.12. **Duration:** This pertains to the length of time an event or condition persists.13. **Time Measurement Tools:** This refers to tools used to measure time, such as clocks, watches, sundials, hourglasses, timers, stopwatches, etc.14. **Time in Literature and Art:** This concerns the representation, perception, and manipulation of time in various artistic and literary contexts.15. **Philosophy of Time:** This involves philosophical view and studies about the nature of time, its changes, and its relation to space.Accordingly, each of these concepts can be further broken down into more specific subclasses.
